author: roberto.bayardo
content:
Interop call notes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/15EatedrJanNxBZGPVASvwq9xgbTs5UxjsDfjpM6ppSY/edit
I didn't quite get the details of the txpool replacement issue Marcin brought up at the end, but someone suggested we bring it to Discord, so maybe someone can reiterate here.

author: marioevz
content:
Basically that Nethermind does not replace blob transactions if the blob count of the replacement transaction is lower I think, please <@334704997122179072> correct me if I'm incorrect.

Currently hive only checks that the blob transactions are replaced if the blob count is equal but the base fee and blob fee are both increased, and <@543900561460822016> suggested that we should not enforce more complex checks in hive and leave it up to the clients, to which I agree

author: g11tech
content:
fyi, ethereumjs has now been able to complete backfill and start front fill on nimbus<>ethereumjs pair

problem: problem is that there are couple (or more) of blocks in range 1886 downwards which are have 1400+ txs each, and ethereumjs by default requests a batch of 100 blocks, but peers were always timing out on requests and not even sending partial data

author: g11tech
content: so ethereumjs wasn't able to complete its backfill, but reducing the request size to 10 resulted into few peers returning data and slowly it got over this heavy segment and now is filling blocks forward from its backfilled block db

author: g11tech
content: all synced
